msgSnippet: That s an interesting point, Kevin. I suppose I m accustomed to a certain interpretation of a JUnit unit test. That interpretation is, If I can get to line X,

That's an interesting point, Kevin. I suppose I'm accustomed to a certain
i=
nterpretation of a JUnit unit test. That interpretation is, "If I can get
t=
o line X, then nothing has gone wrong so far." For that reason,
"assertTrue=
(true)" doesn't speak to me -- it's the same as a blank line.

I would argu=
e that using the identifier "success" communicates more
precisely than "ass=
ertTrue(true)", however. The latter can be written
anywhere to mean anythin=
g; however, the former can only mean "the test was
successful," otherwise d=
on't call it "success". :)

Did the test not perfectly reveal my intentions=
 as written?

While it's true that more detail can better reveal the coder'=
s intentions,
don't conclude that one must always provide that detail in al=
l situations.
That generally leads to someone else wondering if the additio=
nal redundant
detail is somehow significant. "If it weren't," he thinks, "t=
hen it
wouldn't be here. It must mean something..." In the end, it leads to=
 more
confusion than it saves.

But this discussion starts to go beyond the=
 scope of unit tests, so let's
not get too far down the path in public... :=
)

J. B. Rainsberger  <rainsber@...>

 doesn't JUnit count asserts?



rainsber@... wrote: The following t=
est case has no assertions...

public void testIllegalArgumentException() {=

=A0=A0=A0 try {
=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0 MyClass myClass =3D new MyClass(null=
);
=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0 fail("Created myClass with null argument.");
=A0=
=A0=A0 }
=A0=A0=A0 catch (IllegalArgumentException success) {
=A0=A0=A0 }
}=


...should I be worried that this test isn't good enough?I find that asser=
ts
improve the readability of the test and can be used to document the
test=
er's intentions.

Cheers,
=A0=A0=A0 Kevin
